resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
The operation took place in several stages:

1-  Using a bronze hook through the nostrils of the corpse, the embalming priests removed the brain.

2-         They cut the left side of the dead to remove the liver, lungs, stomach and intestines and put them in four vases, the canopy vases, each topped with a lid representing the head of one of the sons of the God falcon Horus (the son of Osiris)to protect the various organs.

3-  The canoes were then placed in the grave, near the mummy. The embalmers did not remove the heart, which had to be weighed by Anubis to determine whether the soul of the deceased was worthy of entering the kingdom of Osiris.

4-   The body was washed in palm wine and immersed in a natron bath, a natural salt that absorbed moisture. This bath lasted only two days when the deceased was very poor but could last up to seventy days when it was a great character.

5-         The deceased’s skin was rubbed with oils so that it would not crack, then the body was filled with sawdust or cloth to preserve its shape.

6-  Embalmers wrapped the body in linen strips. Between the strips, they slipped lucky amulets intended to protect the body and help the soul to enter the kingdom of Osiris.

7-  A mask was placed on the face of the mummy and then placed in a coffin called a sarcophagus. The oldest were simple wooden crates. But from 2,000 B.C., the richest of the dead took the form of the body and were often painted or decorated with gold leaf. The mummy of Pharaoh Tutankhamen was protected from three human-shaped sarcophagi, one of which was entirely made of gold.

But from 2,000 B.C., the richest of the dead took the form of the body and were often painted or decorated with gold leaf. The mummy of Pharaoh Tutankhamen was protected from three human-shaped sarcophagi, one of which was entirely made of gold.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text:
It is difficult to talk about Egypt without talking about mummies:

Mummification was to prevent the decomposition of a body by embalming it to dry out slowly. The embalmment was placed under the protection of Anubis, the jackal-headed god. The legend of the first mummy is Osiris, killed by his brother Seth then resurrected as a bird and became the protector of the dead.
